TheNation
Young adults in mental turmoil
STEPHEN LUNN SOCIAL AFFAIRS EDITOR
781 words
23 July 2022
The Australian
AUSTLN
Australian
3
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

Young Australians are bearing the brunt of the nations mental health crisis, with almost half of all women aged 16-24 reporting a disorder in 2020-21.

Just under 40 per cent of the nations 16-24-year-olds, 1.1 million people, had a mental health condition in 2020-21, far higher than the overall proportion of 21.4 per cent for all adults, a landmark new report by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveals.

But for younger women the picture is especially grim, the latest ABS National Study of Mental Health and Wellbeing reveals.

Over 46 per cent of females aged 16-24 reported some form of mental condition in 2020-21, compared to 31 per cent for males.

More than four in 10 of these women had an anxiety condition such as social phobia or panic disorder in 2020-21, around twice the rate of males. And, while one in seven 16-24-year-olds overall had an affective disorder such as depression or bipolar, this rose to almost 20 per cent for women.

The 2021 study, based on survey responses of more than 5500 households nationally, reports a significant jump in the prevalence of mental health conditions from the previous study in 2007, in which 26 per cent of 16-24-year-olds had a mental health condition within a 12-month period.

Another disturbing marker for young women, reported on for the first time in the new study, was self-harming. One in four females aged 16-34 had self-harmed in their lifetime and 7 per cent had done so in the previous 12 months.

Experts say the isolating impact of the pandemic, the dark side of social media and concerns about the state of the planet likely sit behind the disturbing data.

Beyond Blue chief executive Georgie Harman said the fact the survey was conducted in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic was only part of the reason for a decline in younger Australians mental health.

Weve seen increasing distress among young people right around the world for many years and there could be many things involved here, from the pandemic to broader issues including job uncertainty, climate anxiety and rising social media use, which by its nature encourages social comparison, Ms Harman said.

Australias deputy chief medical officer for mental health, Ruth Vine, said worsening mental health among young people was causing concern in many countries.

There has been increasing levels of distress and anxiety in this cohort that predated Covid, but it has likely been exacerbated by Covid, with issues such as disrupted schooling, Dr Vine said.

Social media is another consideration. It can be good in terms of connection but can also be a harm if its leading to harassing behaviours. And young people are worried about global concerns as well, she said.

The study paints an overall picture of national mental health broadly similar to 2007. Fifteen years ago, 20 per cent of Australians reported having a mental health condition in the previous 12 months, rising to 21.5 per cent, or 4.2 million people.

More than 3.3 million people said they had an anxiety disorder in the previous 12 months. And 650,800 people (3.3 per cent of 16-85-year-olds) had a substance use disorder in 2020-21, whether it be alcohol or drugs.

Around 8.6 million 16-85-year-old Australians, four in 10, have experienced a mental health condition in their lifetime, the study finds.

While 25 per cent of adult females had a mental health condition in 2020-21 compared to 18 per cent of men, they were also more likely to seek professional help.

In 2020-21, 3.4 million Australians aged 16-85 years (17.5 per cent) saw a health professional for their mental health, the report said. More than one in five (22.8 per cent) females saw a health professional for their mental health, compared with one in eight males (12.2 per cent). The study also looked at the issue of suicide, finding nearly 17 per cent of 16-85 year-old Australians had experienced serious suicidal thoughts or behaviours in their lifetime, and 5 per cent had attempted to take their own life.

The ABS report noted that mental ill-health does not define an individuals life. We acknowledge that people are living productive, purposeful and meaningful lives with mental ill-health, it said. If you or someone you know requires assistance or support, contact: Lifeline: 13 11 14 or Beyond Blue: 1300 224 636

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document AUSTLN0020220722ei7n00029


Inquirer
YOUNG ARE IN DANGER OF BEING LEFT BEHIND
TOM DUSEVIC, NATIONAL CHIEF REPORTER
2236 words
23 July 2022
The Australian
AUSTLN
Australian
19
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

Labors promise of a better future must start by helping those to whom it belongs In the giddy, round-midnight moments after claiming victory on May 21, Anthony Albanese steadied himself before the tipsy mosh at his feet and promised to run a government guided by two principles.

No one left behind because we should always look after the disadvantaged and the vulnerable, the prime minister-elect said.

But also no one held back, because we should always support aspiration and opportunity. Albanese addressed parents in public housing, just like his own single mum Maryanne, hoping each of them would be able to tell their child no matter where you live or where you come from, in Australia the doors of opportunity are open to us all.

Improving the life chances of our young people is the ultimate test for Labors opportunity agenda. After all, our teens and 20- somethings have made the biggest sacrifices during the pandemic, and theyll be paying off Covid-19 debt for years.

Its in our national ethos, and interest, to get as many young people trained for the jobs of the future, to lift productivity growth, and run the economy faster to adjust to a rapidly ageing society.

Removing barriers for young Australians to succeed in work, helping them build wealth and a stake in the housing market, and improve their mental health, is about as on brand as it gets for Albanese and Jim Chalmers, the boy from working-class Logan, in Brisbanes south.

Nine weeks after winning a paleo-diet majority with 33 per cent of the primary vote, Labor begins its parliamentary quest to revamp inclusion, while confronted with a budget morass it now owns and must explain to voters, because the political class contested an election on vibe, personalities and a fiscal chimera of prosperity on a stick.

Risk-averse Albo the campaigner is trying to shift into PM Large, telling this newspaper his legislative agenda will go beyond what Labor committed to during the campaign. That is hard to envisage within the budget constraint, although there has been a $40bn upturn in the underlying cash balance for the financial year that ended last month.

To wit, Albaneses mandate involves providing cost-of-living relief, a promise of real wage growth, expanded childcare, skills training and support for manufacturing, and a mid-range emissions reduction target through more renewable energy that will soon face a political examination.

On prevailing electoral demographics, and myopia, the major parties did not genuinely court young voters at the May poll. In fact, they opted to tilt advantage to homeowning Gen Xers and tax-exempt baby boomers in their sunset years. One of the few policy innovations Labor offered was its joint-equity housing scheme, targeting first-home buyers, those stranded after a divorce and low-income families.

The Help to Buy scheme would cover up to 10,000 loans a year for Australian citizens with a taxable income of up to $90,000 for individuals and up to $120,000 for couples. Labor said it would provide an equity injection of up to 40 per cent of the purchase price of a new home and up to 30 per cent for an existing home.

Housing affordability should trump temporary cost-of-living snarls in our political economy, yet it depends where you sit on the floor space-debt continuum.

An over-eager Reserve Bank may now be saying relax about mortgage stress; the one-third of households with no debt and one-third who rent may well be. But with interest rates rising, and property prices tumbling, the borrowers with the smallest savings buffers and vulnerable to negative equity are likely to be recent entrants into the market: young people.

A new OECD report on housing taxation reveals how the game has changed, with home ownership rates plummeting by 40 pernetage points since 1981 for the bottom fifth of earners aged 25 to 34. Younger generations will likely not be able to rely on housing as a vehicle for wealth accumulation in the same way that previous generations have done, the OECD said.

The budget is dire, claims the Treasurer, the savings identified amounting to a weeks worth of fiscal bingeing by the previous tenants. Chalmers will be making a declaration to parliament on Thursday, with new forecasts for inflation, growth and the budget (in the way, way-out years) likely to show a significant downgrade since the April pre-election update.

But the resilient, if now very tight, labour market remains the nations best asset: 3.5 per cent unemployment and a 7 per cent rise in full-time jobs over pre-pandemic levels is a stunning achievement, the $1 trillion debt and the RBAs extraordinary foray into printing money and pumping up asset prices notwithstanding.

Officials are determined to lock in full employment, which is likely to be a 4 per cent jobless rate. Underemployment has also declined in recent months and job vacancies are at historically high levels across most industries, RBA governor Philip Lowe told The Australian Strategic Business Forum.

This all suggests that the growth in demand in the Australian economy is pushing up against the capacity of the economy to meet that demand, he added.

Thats the context for macro policy normalisation, meaning the emergency has passed, with Chalmers switching into budget-repair mode and the RBA trying to run the gauntlet of raising official interest rates without crashing the economy. Beating down demand, massaging inflation psychology, and maintaining confidence amid falling home values is the unenviable task as the global outlook sours. But thats the job. Will the stewards nail a soft landing?

Rich Insight principal Chris Richardson says the labour force results are magnificent numbers for the nation. What we dont know is if they are sustainable. With interest rates rising, China cooling and commodity prices falling, that all makes it harder to sustain, Richardson tells Inquirer.

Despite the lowest jobless rate since 1974 and best-ever workforce participation, there is a danger some of our most vulnerable young people are missing out, having been hit by the pandemics effects on their job-switching prospects, future earnings, educational attainment and mental health. Economists call it scarring.

A new study by think tank e61 Institute, in partnership with the Paul Ramsay Foundation, found early evidence of scarring on human capital accumulation, with a sharp increase in the share of young men who are not in employment, education or training during the Covid-19 pandemic.

By using microdata on individuals, e61 identified four groups most vulnerable to long-term scarring effects. The authors say policies should be designed to break down barriers for young workers not well matched to their jobs; those who have not worked for a long time; men in their early 20s neither working nor studying; and students who have been disproportionately affected by school closures and remote learning E61 found that despite the recovery, long-term unemployment rates for young workers have been elevated since the global financial crisis and continue to rise.

Most notably, there has been a clear increase in the very long-term unemployed young people who are unemployed for two years or more, they write.

Since the GFC, young workers have become more likely than older workers to be very long-term unemployed. This is surprising and potentially concerning given that many young workers will not have had the opportunity to even work for two years.

As well, a key indicator of youth disengagement is the share of people who are not in employment, education or training. Rising educational attainment caused the share of disengaged youth to decline over the 1990s and 2000s. Since the GFC, however, the share of people aged 20-24 that are neither working nor studying has stopped falling; during the pandemic, there was a notable increase in the share of disengaged males E61s program director Dan Andrews tells Inquirer prioritising the preservation of jobs over labour mobility entailed an implicit intergenerational trade-off.

Over the first six months, JobKeeper shielded the intangible fabric of the economy by binding workers to firms, says Andrews, a former RBA and Treasury official and until recently the OECDs head of structural policy. Overall, this was good for productivity but putting the economy in the deep freeze was highly disruptive to those on the cusp of major life transitions. Andrews says this included young people relying on job mobility to overcome early career skill mismatches or lockdown affected sectors, such as hospitality, the port of labour market entry.

Clearly, those at key junctures in their education were particularly affected, he says. Young people lack voice in the political system, and there is a risk that they emerge as casualties of the pandemic once macroeconomic and immigration policy normalises.

In his address to our forum, Lowe said many of the challenges we face would be made easier by stronger growth in productivity. He said theres a limit to pumping up demand: The supply side matters too, and increasingly so. Lowe has never wavered on this vital message, and perhaps the time for uplift will come, as scarcity closes in and a new team in Canberra searches for a new model to deliver a growth economy.

Stronger productivity growth means a bigger economic pie and higher living standards. It can also put downward pressure on prices and inflation, Lowe said.

Further, strong productivity growth provides governments with a greater capability to fund the many services that the public values. And it is the only way to sustain stronger growth in real wages. The strategic challenge for us as a nation is to do what we reasonably can to lift our productivity growth. The good news here is that there is no shortage of ideas on how to do this. What has been lacking is political will. Chalmers is talking more about the supply side, emphasising a switch in the October budget to spending that improves the productive side of the economy; the previous government, politically timid, and out of policy puff at the end of three terms and as many PMs, did not advance the ball on productivity.

There is no opportunity society as Labor envisages it without a productivity dividend, which is spread across the whole community, but where the pain of adjustment is borne in the short-term by discreet groups of workers on the frontline of change.

Labors Jobs and Skills Summit in early September will deal with some of these issues, but addressing entrenched disadvantage will require bespoke solutions, which are always expensive first up.

While cost blowouts are front of mind, one of the least spoken about aspects of the National Disability Insurance Scheme is its workforce participation element. It would be surprising if this were not revived. It must be.

University of Melbourne economics professor Jeff Borland says the best policy for assisting young people to get into work is by making growth in total employment as fast as possible.

Just as young people are worst affected when the labour market slows, they benefit most when the labour market recovers, Borland says.

We saw this in the 1990s and we are seeing it again with employment growth for young people occurring more rapidly than for older age groups during the bounce-back from Covid-19. Last weeks labour force data shows the percentage of young people employed is now 6.1 percentage points above where it was in March 2020, compared to an increase of 2.6 percentage points for those aged 25 to 64 and 0.2 percentage point for those aged 65 plus.

Unfortunately, the experience is that a strong labour market is not likely to be sufficient by itself to get into employment groups of young people who face high barriers to obtaining work, says Borland of those stuck in depressed regions or who have had their learning disrupted Once you know the groups who are finding it difficult to get into work, then its possible to target policies at the barriers they are facing, he adds.

In very general terms, the types of policies that can improve employment outcomes are those that first give opportunities for young people to become job ready and improve their skills and, second, give opportunities to establish contact with work, for example, through career guidance and paid internship programs. E61s Andrews says the tendency for policy to excessively protect incumbents at the expense of entrants is an increasing problem in OECD countries. We saw it during the crisis; well never know how many potential great ideas or new firms were killed off by red tape or vested interests, he says.

This new research is just another reminder of why young people need to be put at the heart of public policy, he says.

Pinpointing those most at risk, through better microdata, as e61 is calling for, will hopefully lead to superior policies for the disadvantaged. Theyre the ones we want to see bursting forth to a better life, by reaching their potential; for whom Albanese and Chalmers must speak and act for, having vowed to construct a wider entry to a world of opportunity.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document AUSTLN0020220722ei7n00023


The-oz
Young and very unwell, what is going on?
Stephen Lunn
613 words
22 July 2022
13:38
The Australian - Online
AUSTOL
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

Anxiety was the most common ailment, followed by depression and substance use disorders.

The mental health of young Australians is in freefall, particularly young women, new data shows, with almost one in two females aged 16-24 having experienced a mental health condition in the last 12 months.

Just under 40% of 16-24 year-old Australians, 1.1 million people, reported having a mental disorder in 2020-21, far higher than the overall proportion of 21.4%for all Australian adults, a landmark new report by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveals.

But for younger women the picture is especially grim, the ABS National Study of Mental Health and Wellbeing, the first comprehensive audit of the nations mental health for 15 years, reveals.

Over 46% of females reported some form of mental condition within the 12 months of 2020-21, compared to 31% for males.

More than four in ten 16-24 year-old females in Australia reported an anxiety condition such as social phobia or panic disorder in that period, around twice the rate as males of the same age.

And while overall one in seven 16-24 year-olds overall reported having an affective disorder such as depression or bipolar, this rose to almost one in five for women across the year.

The survey of 5,500 households across Australia paints an overall picture of mental health broadly similar to 2007 when the last National Study of Mental Health and Wellbeing was conducted. Fifteen years ago 20% of Australians reported having had a mental health condition in the previous 12 months, a number that now sits at 21.5%, or 4.2 million people.

But the big shift has been in the young. In 2007, 26% of 16-24 year-olds had a mental health condition, compared to 39.6% in 2020-21.

This has been a trend causing concern in many countries, Australias deputy chief medical officer for mental health Ruth Vine said.

There has been increasing levels of distress and anxiety in this cohort that predated Covid, but it has likely been exacerbated by Covid, with issues such as disrupted schooling. Dr Vine said.

Social media is another consideration. It can be good in terms of connection but can also be a harm if its leading to harassing behaviours.

And young people are worried about global concerns as well, Dr Vine said

The study covers lifetime mental health, noting that 44% of Australians aged between 16 and 85, more than 8.5 million, have experienced a mental disorder at some time in their life.

In 2020-21 it was just over one in five, or 4.2 million people, ABS head of health and disability statistics Linda Fardell said.

Anxiety was the most common group of mental disorders - 16.8% of all Australians had an anxiety disorder, 7.5% had an affective disorder such as depression, while 3.3% had a substance use disorder.

The study also notes how people are trying to manage their mental health.

Some 17.5% (3.4 million) of Australians had at least one consultation with a health professional for their mental health in 2020-21, Ms Fardell said. General practitioners were the most common type of health professional consulted.

Over 850,000 Australians accessed at least one digital service such as a crisis support line or counselling service for their mental health.

Women are more likely to seek support, the data shows, with more than one in five (22.8%) seeing a health professional for their mental health compared with one in eight (12.2%) for males.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document AUSTOL0020220722ei7m00106


Nation
Mental health of young women in freefall
STEPHEN LUNN
716 words
22 July 2022
13:30
The Australian - Online
AUSTOL
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

The mental health of young Australians is in freefall, particularly young women, new data shows, with almost one in two females aged 16-24 having experienced a mental health condition in the last 12 months.

Just under 40 per cent of 16-24 year-old Australians, 1.1 million people, reported having a mental disorder in 2020-21, far higher than the overall proportion of 21.4 per cent for all Australian adults, a landmark new report by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveals.

But for younger women the picture is especially grim, the ABS National Study of Mental Health and Wellbeing, the first comprehensive audit of the nations mental health for 15 years, reveals.

Over 46 per cent of females reported some form of mental condition within the 12 months of 2020-21, compared to 31 per cent for males.

More than four in ten 16-24 year-old females in Australia reported an anxiety condition such as social phobia or panic disorder in that period, around twice the rate as males of the same age.

Data from last year's census has been released, revealing one in 10 Australians believe they have a mental health condition. The Australians Health Editor Natasha Robinson says there has been an increase in mental health issues in young people as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. I think these numbers have been really exacerbated by the pandemic,\" she told Sky News Australia. Young people were hit the hardest by the pandemic.

And while overall one in seven 16-24 year-olds overall reported having an affective disorder such as depression or bipolar, this rose to almost one in five for women across the year.

The survey of 5500 households across Australia paints an overall picture of mental health broadly similar to 2007 when the last National Study of Mental Health and Wellbeing was conducted. Fifteen years ago 20 per cent of Australians reported having had a mental health condition in the previous 12 months, a number that now sits at 21.5 per cent, or 4.2 million people.

But the big shift has been in the young. In 2007, 26 per cent of 16-24 year-olds had a mental health condition, compared to 39.6 per cent in 2020-21.

This has been a trend causing concern in many countries, Australias deputy chief medical officer for mental health Ruth Vine said.

There has been increasing levels of distress and anxiety in this cohort that predated Covid, but it has likely been exacerbated by Covid, with issues such as disrupted schooling.

Social media is another consideration. It can be good in terms of connection but can also be a harm if its leading to harassing behaviours.

And young people are worried about global concerns as well.

The study covers lifetime mental health, noting that 44 per cent of Australians aged between 16 and 85, more than 8.5 million, have experienced a mental disorder at some time in their life.

In 2020-21 it was just over one in five, or 4.2 million people, ABS head of health and disability statistics Linda Fardell said.

Anxiety was the most common group of mental disorders 16.8 per cent of all Australians had an anxiety disorder, 7.5 per cent had an affective disorder such as depression, while 3.3 per cent had a substance use disorder.

The study also notes how people are trying to manage their mental health.

Some 17.5 per cent (3.4 million) of Australians had at least one consultation with a health professional for their mental health in 2020-21, Ms Fardell said. General practitioners were the most common type of health professional consulted.

Over 850,000 Australians accessed at least one digital service such as a crisis support line or counselling service for their mental health.

Women are more likely to seek support, the data shows, with more than one in five (22.8 per cent) seeing a health professional for their mental health compared with one in eight (12.2 per cent) for males.

If you or someone you know requires assistance or support, contact: Lifeline: 13 11 14 or Beyond Blue: 1300 224 636

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document AUSTOL0020220722ei7m00105


Columnist
Large trumps small
Anna Caldwell
756 words
22 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
13
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

Its irresponsible for big corporates to encourage staff to work from home due to Covid

Big corporate players who have gone harder than the public health advice and encouraged their office staff to work from home as this Covid winter wave takes hold want you to think they are being socially responsible.

Wrong.

This is an opportunistic reach to masquerade social responsibility without a care in the world for the small business owners and retailers theyll cripple on the way.

Such a call to forge ahead with a work from home-friendly Covid policy, in a big old nod to the zoom class, is in fact deeply irresponsible and a fast track back to the dark days of 2020.

As this winter wave takes hold, every day we are faced with doomsayers who want to return to the dim days of lockdowns and misery.

We have to accept these kinds of weirdos will exist forevermore some people just like living under a doona and would like everyone else to do the same.

But, this week, seeing corporate giants like Telstra and Westpac issuing advice to encourage tens of thousands of staff to work from home was a concerning turning point.

Alex Badenoch, a Telstra group executive said in a statement: We are strongly encouraging our people to work from home if they can, wear a mask when they cant socially distance, and get their booster shot if theyre eligible. Westpac declared there was no requirement to be in the office. It came as Covid cases creep up to near record levels but we must keep this in perspective.

In NSW on Thursday there were just 55 people with Covid in intensive care units. We have the capacity for hundreds.

With massive vaccination rates the envy of the world and more than two years of knowing precisely what a Covid symptom looks like, we are more than equipped to manage ourselves without being encouraged to go home.

The moves from Telstra and Westpac followed updated advice from Chief Medical Officer Paul Kelly this week.

Professor Kelly on Tuesday said the AHPPC called on employers to allow work from home if feasible.

It is not a mandate. It is not official NSW government policy. It is not even enforced national health policy. Big corporates in Australia have long been masters of virtue signalling and moonlighting in social policy when they should be sticking the business of business. And here we go again.

The impact of the decisions by Telstra and Westpac on retailers and small businesses as well as CBDs will be tangible. If other big corporates follow in their footsteps, it will be worse than tangible it will be devastating.

Just as weve started to breathe life back into our CBDs the last thing we need to do is encourage people to go home again.

Anthony Albanese has been wisely measured on the topic. Pressed earlier this week on why governments wont introduce stricter Covid mandates, he pointed to two things mental health concerns of ongoing restrictions and our high vaccination rates.

Pressed multiple times on whether businesses should send staff home, Albanese has refrained from issuing an edict, instead acknowledging businesses would make their own decisions.

He also acknowledged the bigger economic picture.

If youre a business that relies upon people coming into the CBD to shop, in retail or hospitality, then your business can be hurt by that as well. So its a matter of getting the balance right. This is smart.

Of course companies and employers should have the authority to try to manage outbreaks in teams and to protect their workforce.

For example, if the NRL institutes a Covid bubble it would do so to save play. But a blanket call encouraging tens of thousands of office workers to go home is a different beast.

It smacks of corporates making decisions that have little impact on them but a big impact on everyone else.

Blended work weeks like two days at home and three days in the office are one of the benefits to workers which have come out of the pandemic. These are here to stay.

But small retailers and hospitality groups, who have already had to adjust to this and been knocked down time and time again, dont need another blow on a corporate whim. Surely we are advanced enough now to stay home when youre sick and go out when youre not.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document DAITEL0020220721ei7m0000d


News
Slats called cops for help
EXCLUSIVE JOSH HANRAHAN
314 words
22 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
28
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

A DESPERATE Michael Slater called police for help after drinking in breach of his bail conditions, in an incident that ultimately saw him arrested and taken to court.

The Daily Telegraph can reveal police performed a welfare check at Slaters unit in Manly late last Thursday night, which sources said came after they received a call from the cricketing legend.

When officers arrived they called NSW Ambulance who took the 52-year-old to Northern Beaches Hospital.

In a statement, a NSW Police spokesman said Slater remained in hospital until Monday when he faced court.

On Monday, 18 July he was escorted to Manly Police Station and charged with breach of bail, appearing at Manly Local Court the same day, the statement read.

Magistrate Megan Greenwood found there had been a breach, but granted Slater bail again and ordered him to abide by the strict conditions of the arrangement. They include that he abstain from alcohol and drugs, be of good behaviour and not contact a number of women who have AVOs against him.

The same court has previously heard Slater (pictured) had been receiving treatment for an alcohol use disorder and other mental health issues at Northern Beaches Hospital.

He is currently facing charges including common assault and stalk/intimidate. During a court hearing last year it was detailed how Slater allegedly bombarded his former partner with 66 harassing and highly offensive text messages and 18 phone calls in a two-and-a-half hour period.

The charges relating to those allegations were eventually dealt with under the Mental Health Act.

Slater lost his job as a commentator at Channel 7 earlier in 2021 after he publicly attacked Scott Morrison on Twitter over not doing enough to get Australians home during the pandemic. He played 74 Tests for Australia between 1993 and 2001.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document DAITEL0020220721ei7m0000b


OpEd
Prioritise help
KELLIE SLOANE
599 words
22 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
31
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

More support is needed for teachers to travail lifes setbacks

NSW students have returned to school this week after holiday plans hampered by severe weather only to face a new wave of Covid.

Theres a resigned inevitability to the cycle of gloom and disruption after four years of fires, floods and pandemic but we cannot accept constant challenge as the norm.

While NAPLAN results show Australian schools have emerged from the pandemic largely unscathed in terms of academic performance around numeracy and literacy, there are continued impacts on childhood development and wellbeing.

Teachers are seeing this first hand: increased anxiety, loss of social skills and pronounced behavioural issues in a cohort of school-starters whove spent half their lives isolated from the usual developmental opportunities that come with play and interaction with other children.

Life Ed (Healthy Harold) is the largest non-Government provider of preventative health education to Australian schoolchildren.

Bookings for our programs that cover social and emotional skills as well as cyber bullying are in high demand.

We recently conducted focus groups with teachers right across the country to find out what is troubling them the most. Student wellbeing was at the top of the list. The stories were consistent across the states and, in many cases, heartbreaking.

Teachers told us about children standing on the sidelines of the playground, unsure of how to join in with basic games; of increased rough play; of increased bullying; of inappropriately mature language learned from too much time online.

Anxiety in parents was broadly observed too. We have parents coming to us daily for advice for their childrens mental health issues we simply arent equipped for this, one Year 5 teacher said. Lets be clear. The wellbeing of our young has been under pressure well before Covid. The protracted isolation during the pandemic has simply exaggerated it.

The Gonski report Growing up Digital revealed that nine out of 10 teachers observed an increase in social and behavioural challenges in 2019 compared to five years earlier. The report focused on the correlation between the increasing amount of time spent by young people online and their emotional and physical health.

While not all screen time is bad for young people, their digital immersion deepened during Covid.

Theres been no significant re-set, rather entrenched poor online habits have been accepted as the norm.

We need to more comprehensively track and measure the wellbeing of children, especially those from areas of disadvantage where the developmental gaps are widest. The data to inform policy development is thin on the ground and largely anecdotal.

One of the few sources of data around early childhood, the 2021 Australian Early Development Census, found that 44 per cent of NSW children were not developmentally on track when they started school.

Rates dropped last year in key areas for the first time since 2009. Our school teachers are some of the best in the world but we cannot expect them to be to counsellors too. The circumstances in which they find themselves are unprecedented. The expectations on them are beyond their capacity. And many are stretched to a point of breaking.

NSW Government measures to reduce paperwork and administration for teachers are a much-needed start.

The scale of stress and uncertainty experienced by children, their families and school communities require multiple interventions.

At the forefront of this should be specialist curriculum-aligned support for teachers to ensure the mental well-being of generation Covid is our priority. Kellie Sloane is the CEO Life Ed Australia

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document DAITEL0020220721ei7m0000x


News
Slater in hospital after calling police for help
EXCLUSIVE JOSH HANRAHAN
316 words
22 July 2022
Courier Mail
COUMAI
CourierMail
16
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

A DESPERATE Michael Slater called police for help after drinking in breach of his bail conditions, during an incident in which he ultimately was arrested and taken to court.

The Courier-Mail can reveal police performed a welfare check at Slaters unit in Manly, Sydney, late last Thursday, which sources said came after they received a call from the cricketing legend.

When officers arrived, they called NSW Ambulance, which took the 52-year-old to Northern Beaches Hospital.

In a statement, a NSW police spokesman said Slater remained in hospital until Monday, when he faced court.

On Monday, 18 July, he was escorted to Manly Police Station and charged with breach of bail, appearing at Manly Local Court the same day, the statement reads.

Magistrate Megan Greenwood found there had been a breach, but granted Slater bail again and ordered him to abide by the strict conditions of the arrangement. They include that he abstain from alcohol and drugs, be of good behaviour and not contact a number of women who have AVOs against him.

The same court has previously heard Slater (pictured) had been receiving treatment for an alcohol use disorder and other mental health issues at Northern Beaches Hospital.

He is facing charges including common assault and stalk/intimidate. During a court hearing last year, it was detailed how Slater allegedly bombarded his former partner with 66 harassing and highly offensive text messages and 18 phone calls in a 2-hour period. The charges relating to those allegations were eventually dealt with under the Mental Health Act.

Slater lost his job as a commentator at Channel 7 in 2021 after he publicly attacked then-prime minister Scott Morrison on Twitter over not doing enough to get Australians home during the pandemic. He played 74 Tests for Australia between 1993 and 2001.

SportsWrap
Your time starts now have a go!
Ian Chesterman
712 words
22 July 2022
Courier Mail
COUMAI
CourierMail
92
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

10 YEARS TO GO! 2023 OUR time starts now. These four words celebrate the reality that we dont need to wait ten years to enjoy the benefits of Brisbane 2032.

The Games legacies can be enjoyed along a green and gold runway that starts today, that will take us to an opening ceremony in Brisbane in 2032, and then a decade beyond that.

There are more than 30 major global sporting competitions coming to Australia along this runway and more are being added. This year alone we will see the Womens World Cup in basketball, the World Road Cycling Championship and the World Short Course Swimming Championship come to our shores.

Next year the Womens World Cup in football, the Commonwealth Games in 2026, the Rugby World Cup for men in 2027 and women in 2029, and the list goes on.

For those 30-plus events, volunteers will be mobilised, sports communities activated, the worlds greatest athletes in their respective sports on display to inspire.

New sports facilities will come online and importantly for Brisbane 2032, community facilities that will have an active life before playing their part in the Games will be then returned to the community. And perhaps most importantly, young Australians and some not-so-young will be inspired to have a go at a sport that best suits their capabilities.

Having a go is an important first step for all of us to achieve and enjoy the many benefits sport can bring. Improving our physical health and our mental health. Bringing communities together and instilling pride. But without having a go in the first place, none of these benefits can be realised.

Theres no question Brisbane and Queensland has embraced these Games and the opportunity it represents. But it is 10 years away and for many, perhaps a little over the horizon.

Thats why we are saying our time starts now. The organising committee has come together and planning is underway. Three levels of government are working well together. The business community has its head down to explore the possibilities over the next 10 years to make a lasting difference to Queensland and Australia.

Importantly, for a Games to be successful, our Australian team must be successful. For that to happen, we need to invest in our sports to create opportunities today for the athletes of tomorrow.

The Australian Olympic Committee and Commonwealth Games Australia have made a submission to government calling for a reset in the way government invests in sport.

Our 10+10 strategy is designed to ensure that proper investment in sport now gives us success in 2032 and for 10 years beyond that. And it is an investment, not a handout.

Success doesnt happen with the flick of a switch. We must also support our athletes to ensure the success of Tokyo continues through Paris 2024, Los Angeles 2028 and through to Brisbane 2032. Once again, Our Time Starts Now.

Our Olympic athletes want to make a difference too. We have seen the inspiration they provided through the gloom of Covid. Across Tokyo and Beijing, our teams energised and inspired our young athletes and communities right across Queensland and our country.

This month in front of 50 schoolchildren on Thursday Island, the AOCs Olympics Unleashed program passed a milestone with 250,000 students nationally now hearing directly from Olympians.

Reaching that mark on Thursday Island during NAIDOC Week was both a happy coincidence and an illustration of the AOCs commitment to reconciliation through sport.

There have been 60 known Indigenous Olympians. The group of 16 who travelled to Tokyo in 2021 was the biggest contingent of Indigenous Australian Olympians ever.

In Tokyo last year, Patty Mills became the first Indigenous flag bearer. He unified and energised the entire team in Tokyo and inspired Australians back home.

That moment and Pattys Boomers winning their bronze medal was magical. We want more Australians engaged and inspired to participate in sport and benefiting from that involvement. Our Olympic sports have something for everyone.

The green and gold runway starts now. We can all have a go now. Our time starts now. IAN CHESTERMAN IS AOC PRESIDENT

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document COUMAI0020220721ei7m00006


SMARTdaily
Youre not on mute
Lauren Ahwan
811 words
21 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
27
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

CAREERS Compensation fears as rude Aussie workers forget how to deal with colleagues

Almost three years of social distancing has left Aussie workers without the skills required to communicate appropriately with their colleagues.

Too much time working remotely has caused many to forget their manners during face-to-face interactions, leading experts to fear a dramatic spike in claims for mental health-related workers compensation.

Centre for Corporate Health founder and psychological services director Rachel Clements says there has already been an increase in workplace reports of aggressive and inappropriate behaviour following Australias transition back to the workplace earlier this year.

People have forgotten their social skills. Theyve forgotten theyre not on mute, Clements says. People are being rude to each other or theyre phrasing or wording things a little bit differently. Sometimes, theres full-on conflict and yelling.

NO FILTER Clements says the stress of the pandemic has left workers feeling tired and burnt out, with little empathy for others.

Working remotely for long periods of time reduces peoples empathy muscle it really does, she says. People are saying what they think now, instead of stopping and thinking before they speak.

Or theyre a bit more sensitive and trying to read things into situations that arent there. While Clements expects a significant increase in psychological injury claims in the coming year, she says other options are available to those with poor work-related mental health.

She says Resilient Me, an early intervention mental health program operated by CFCHs sister company Resilia, can reduce workplace depression, anxiety and stress by more than 75 per cent and improve wellbeing by more than 40 per cent.

PEOPLE FIRST APPROACH Managing worker anxiety around returning to the office has been key to law firm Maddocks efforts to minimise fractious relations that can lead to psychological injury claims.

We said right from the beginning of the pandemic that our number one priority was our peoples mental health, says people and culture director Deborah Stonley.

During the pandemic, people were dealing with issues of isolation, increased workloads, reduced social interaction and fatigue from managing working from home.

These are still issues as people are coming back to the office. Weve had a staggered approach to returning to work so that we dont all need to be in the office immediately but people have been encouraged to head in on a day that their (immediate) colleagues are going to be there so they can reestablish those reconnections with each other. Covid-safe work lunches and morning teas have helped to reacquaint staff, while managers have spoken openly about their own struggles in a bid to break down the stigma surrounding poor mental health, Stonley says. The proactive measures have seen calls to an employee assistance program return to pre-Covid levels, after tripling at the height of pandemic lockdowns, she says.

MENTAL HEALTHS STEEP DECLINE In Victoria, which endured the worlds longest lockdown during Covid-19 restrictions, claims for compensation for psychological injury are expected to account for at least a third of all WorkSafe claims within the next decade, says personal injury lawyer Gabrielle Verhagen, from Gordon Legal.

But to be eligible for workers compensation, Verhagen says claims must include evidence the injury was a direct result of the complainants employment.

She warns the claims process can be lengthy and could further exacerbate a workers poor mental health. Something workers need to weigh up (before proceeding with a claim) is whether (their health condition) will be a long-term condition and how much treatment and support they need, she says.

If they only need short-term treatment and recovery (is quick) then maybe they dont want to go down that path (of lodging a compensation claim). Regardless, all workplace incidents should be documented by the employee in case they decide to lodge a later claim, Verhargen says.

She says assistance is available for those who do not have the financial means to seek professional advice.

Managing mental health Be aware of, and avoid the things that trigger your illness Monitor your stress levels Take tea and lunch breaks and, if necessary, go off-site to reduce stress Exercise during your lunch break Maintain your medication routine. Employers may be able to provide a private place for you to store or take your medication Maintain a routine when you feel unwell Develop a healthy way to release anger, such as an off-site walk, meeting with or phoning a friend during your breaks Learn and use relaxation techniques Use your network of family or friends, caseworker or community links Maintain behaviour appropriate to the situation If you are unwell or unhappy about something, speak to a trusted person in confidence Source: headspace

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document DAITEL0020220720ei7l00001


TheNation
Workers staying put as costs climb
STEPHEN LUNN SOCIAL AFFAIRS EDITOR
460 words
21 July 2022
The Australian
AUSTLN
Australian
7
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

Australians are increasingly jittery about the economy despite low unemployment levels, with more planning to hang on to the jobs they have as they grapple with the rising cost of living.

Almost half of the nations employees say they are struggling to meet their basic living costs, with petrol, housing and electricity their highest concern, a new study has found.

The latest quarterly employee sentiment index from software company ELMO finds just 14 per cent rate the economy as secure, down from 19 per cent in the June 2021 quarter.

The rising uncertainty is quickly putting paid to any notion of a Great Resignation in Australia, with the survey of more than 1000 Australian employees revealing a sharp drop in those considering a career change, down from 29 per cent in the first quarter of 2022 to 25 per cent in June. And fewer workers are actively seeking a new job, although the number of employees anticipating a pay rise within a year rose by six percentage points to 56 per cent.

Cost of living pressures are also having an adverse effect on their overall wellbeing, particularly for Generation Z workers, the survey finds. However, employees in Gen Z are around twice as likely to be interviewing for a role with a new company than other generations, at 19 per cent (in the past three months) compared to millennials 12 per cent, Gen X 8 per cent and baby boomers 5 per cent, the report states.

ELMO Software chief executive Danny Lessem said the June quarter had seen a significant shift in employee priorities due to the broader economic conditions in Australia.

The overwhelming feeling of uncertainty is prompting more employees to remain with their current employer with the expectation they will be rewarded for their contribution and loyalty, Mr Lessem said.

As Covid-19 continues to affect employer/employee relations and how jobs are done, the survey revealed a reversal of the trend of worker burnout.

In June 2021, 42 per cent of workers said they felt burnt out, a figure which had risen to 46 per cent by the March quarter this year. Now it is back to 42 per cent, but still worryingly high. More workers are prepared to take a mental health day, with 16 per cent reporting having done so in the past three months compared to 14 per cent in the quarter prior. While most employers were encouraging the return to the office in recent months, its clear the cost of living pressures, which includes rising commuting and petrol prices, together with the colder winter months. means employees will favour more flexible, hybrid and remote working conditions, Mr Lessem said.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

AGED CARE NEEDS HELP HAVING an elderly parent in an aged-care facility has been a difficult situation to deal with over the past 12 months.

I am certainly grateful to the nursing staff and other essential workers in my mothers facility, and I would not begrudge any of them receiving the $750 Covid emergency payment that has been reinstated by the Albanese government.

But as your Editorial (C-M, Jul 18) noted, reports that staffing level rosters in the next few weeks could reach 30 per cent unfilled will have a severe impact on the care of vulnerable loved ones.

If there are nurses who can be utilised from the ADF it is a no-brainer that they must be enacted again by the Albanese government. My parents mental health has been severely tested over the past six months. Continual lockdowns at her facility have had a dramatic effect on her mental wellbeing.

Being locked in her room due to just one Covid case in a 120-bed facility has in some ways been overkill, but understandable in the extreme measures that are needed to protect other residents.

But if the ADF can be used to address a nursing shortfall it is incumbent on the Prime Minister to ensure our elderly get through this third wave of an epidemic that regrettably targets them because of their age and circumstance.

Paul Henderson, Wynnum

THE Covid pandemic was being controlled by our governments, protecting the people using best medical advice until the mercenary forces of crass capitalism overtook this balanced approach with the mantra of freedom from mandates and let her rip mentality that allowed Covid-19 to thrive.

The Covid incidence rate is alarmingly high and deaths continue to escalate, especially in the aged and disadvantaged sectors because of government failures.

Science has all the answers but politicians only heed advice that is deemed politically advantageous.

Max Tanzer, Elliott Heads

AS a retired pharmacist, aged 69, who has had four Covid vaccine shots, I unfortunately contracted Covid last week.

After deteriorating, I decided to bu my own antiviral at $1153, as I only had one approved condition and did not qualify for PBS supply.

Given the enormous cost of having people in hospital, and health professionals run off their feet, why not give doctors more flexibility to prescribe drugs that could take the pressure off our collapsing and overburdened health workers?

I was able to stay out of hospital because the drugs worked so well. Is this another economic equation that our governments play dollars versus sense?

Paul Risitano, Coorparoo

APPOINTEES REQUIRE MERIT HOT on the heels of the malodorous revelations about the integrity of state government practices and the political machinations of its members comes the revelation by the Grattan Institute that 21 per cent of federal government appointees to responsible government entities are there as a result of jobs for mates (C-M, Jul 18).

Considering Australian governments are adept at taking the political high ground with foreign governments over human rights and corruption issues, these revelations make us look like hypocrites.

While some political appointees may be eminently qualified for some of these appointments due to their previous careers, the fact remains that in these cases a transparent, merit-based selection process has been usurped to provide a reward for service to the political incumbents.

This is bad policy because decision-making in entities controlled by political appointees is sometimes compromised, since difficult and often necessary decisions may not be implemented in the public interest but more in consideration of the desires of the appointees previous political affiliations.

Societies should harness the talents and abilities of the most competent members, and it is only through merit-based selections for the leaders of societys instrumentalities that the best decisions are made, leading to beneficial outcomes.

The suggestion then that a review panel be established to scrutinise these appointments to government positions is timely and meritorious.

Geoff Roberts, Brendale

ABORTION PLOT IN response to the article Abortion move by ministers (C-M, Jul 18), the so-called womens ministers would better serve all Australian women by not wasting time on shoring up their already deadly laws and instead support pregnant women who are constrained by circumstances or the antagonism of others.

It is these types of factors rather than ideology that drive most women towards abortion, but rarely do we see any recognition of this among many parliamentarians.

In the wake of the reversal of Roe v Wade in the US, which simply returns the onus back to the states to decide on their laws, the abortion zealots here are driving in the opposite direction of ensuring federal support which is ultimately about ensuring federal funding for abortion.

Where this is a shortfall in state funding, the federal government will be expected to pick up the tab.

Would not most women be better served by seeking to provide services to support pregnant women and their families either through government departments or organisations largely run by volunteers who do not qualify for funds if they are philosophically opposed to abortion?

It seems taxpayers money can only be directed to achieve one outcome which results in the death of an unborn human and the abandonment of others who are still left with the problems which initiated the initial crisis.

Dr Donna Purcell, president, Cherish Life Queensland

TRADIE SKILLS DRAIN IT was interesting reading about the low intake of tradies etc to do flood work and move to Queensland (C-M, Jul 18).

The incentive is pitiful. Does the state government know how hard it is to get trade positions filled?

Our youth were all pushed to be part of the Smart State and go to university etc.

Well, we have reaped what we have sown and we now have a lack of tradespeople. Offering incentives now is good but the pool of tradies for the foreseeable future is slim.

Terry Dale, Oxley

NO TIME FOR GROUP HUGS IF Mike OConnors column (C-M, Jul 18) proves correct, federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers is embarking on a Brave New World campaign to control our very id.

It seems Labor is planning strategies to tell us when were happy, when were not and even if were a bit melancholy.

No one knows how they will achieve this, but you can bet itll cost megabucks. OConnor tells us New Zealand Prime Minister, and head of Hobbiton, Jacinda Ardern has already tried and failed, so why would Australia want to follow suit?

Conducting group hugs isnt going to help anyone, so dont waste our time Mr Treasurer. Richard Marman, Meridan Plains

The-oz
Making news: Julie Bishop and Sammy Robinson have the ick
Jenna Clarke
1383 words
18 July 2022
19:53
The Australian - Online
AUSTOL
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

All the news that's fit to mint.

What's happening in (The) Oz today:

ACT bans petrol cars

Grab a blanket Victoria, it's about to get Victorian

Nurses in NSW are not happy

Debate over a new Covid iso period

Young people think Super is super

Sammy Robinson's ex to punch on to win her back

Julie Bishop is thriving post break-up

Good morning!

In breaking news, it's cold.

Yes, it's winter but people in Victoria this morning may be waking up in a cold sweat as the Australian Energy Market Operator is back with a fresh warning.

The Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) is saying the national electricity market faces a new crisis with looming gas shortages in Victoria which could cause a threat to \"system security\".

The Australian - the cashmere throw to our electric blanket - reports that Lochard Energy's Iona gas storage facility in Victoria is on track \"to fall to an all-time low\" of just 6 petajoules on July 31 with the depletion of inventories leading to the risk of \"total system\" gas supply shortfalls for the state.

Cool [sarcasm font].

Cars are cancelled

Well ones that drink petrol will be in less than 10 years.

The ACT government - different from the federal government that lives there - announced on Monday that by 2030, about 80 to 90% of new vehicles sold in the nation's capital will be zero emission vehicles. No new petrol vehicles will enter the market from 2035.

instagram

Many people will replace their vehicles over the next 10 years, the ACT's energy and emissions reduction minister Shane Rattenbury said. Were not going to take vehicles off the road, but we want to stop new petrol vehicles coming into the system to stop the problem getting worse; then, we can focus on transitioning those older vehicles out.

Everyone is tired

But our front line healthcare workers are especially fatigued as Covid enters it's third year and we're told to expect another wave in mere weeks.

On Monday, WA reached a milestone with its one millionth Covid case being recorded and with more than 400 people now in hospital, just 19 are in ICU, only two for Covid and none need a ventilator. The WA government is holding out on making masks mandatory again.

Meanwhile in Sydney about 60 nurses from two of western Sydney's biggest hospitals walked off the job on Monday morning to highlight staffing levels harming patient care with some nurses saying the hospitals are completely overcrowded at the moment.

Anyone else who comes to Westmead here is going to be treated outside because there is no room inside, a group of protesting nurses told Sky News as hospitals prepare for a wave of new infections to peak next month.

The nurses at Blacktown hospital did the same.

At the #nswnursestrike

Nearly 3000 health workers are currently in isolation in NSW.

NSW Premier Dominic Perrottet then said the flu is more severe than current strains of Covid.

The latest health data shows there have been 113 deaths from the flu out of 187,431 laboratory-confirmed cases in Australia this year.

In comparison, there have been 1383 deaths from more than 1 million Covid cases this month alone.

While it is likely that the flu season has already peaked, the new wave of Covid is yet to reach its highest infection rate, projected to peak in August.

Cut it iso?

Perrottet was taking no prisoners on Monday with regard to Covid.

He is also calling for a balanced approach when considering isolation requirements, advocating for a reduced isolation period at the end of the BA.4 and BA.5 wave.

As it stands you catch the spicy cough, see ya in seven days. Perrottet suggested maybe five days would be better.

As we move through the next phase of the pandemic we need to balance out the competing health issues, mental health issues, educational outcomes for our children, allowing people the opportunity to go to work, he said.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese didn't have a bar of it, saying now isn't the time to talk about cutting iso requirements as places like WA and SA will likely not experience their next Covid wave for six weeks.

Albo isn't biting when it comes to cutting the iso debate. Yet.

Paul J. Keating would be so proud of you

According to new research, conducted by a Superannuation fund mind you, Covid has prompted a rethink among younger Australians when it comes to superannuation.

Almost half of the 18-34 year old Australians surveyed viewed their superannuation as more important now than since the start of the pandemic, according to a survey by super fund Equip.

And nearly half of respondents overall (46%) have made voluntary super contributions, with as many as two in five starting to tip more in before they hit their 30s.

Equip CEO Scott Cameron said Aussies appeared to be taking their super more seriously from a younger age.

Young Australians are thinking about their financial plans much more than they have previously, Cameron said. It is encouraging to see that younger people are prioritising their finances, and seeing value in contributing more to their super early in their careers.

The survey also revealed those under-35 were hit especially hard by the pandemic, with about a third losing working hours and almost one in seven losing their jobs or granted a leave of absence.

But, nearly a third had the opposite experience, 28% emerged from the pandemic with greater income. While 27% emerged with more disposable income than before.

Julie Bishop's ick factor

Julie Bishop - former Foreign Minister, the woman who made partner of a massive law firm, represented asbestos manufacturer James Hardie then climbed the ranks of the Liberal party and became its deputy federal leader for more than 10-years - broke up with her longterm boyfriend, David Panton. But she's fine. She is booked and busy.

So fine she managed to turn a cringe TV interview into a promo for her latest corporate gig as an \"ambassador\" for Perth-based mining company Mineral Resources.

instagram

So how does a successful woman heal from heart break. I hear using $100 bills earned from your plethora of post political jobs and board appointments helps.

Julie and David reportedly broke up when he took her out to dinner recently.

Meanwhile this guy is going to fight for his ex

Literally.

Jordan Simi, a podcaster and influencer who is set to make his boxing debut against NRL great Justin Hodges, is only getting in the ring on Wednesday night to win back his ex-girlfriend - fellow influencer anf founder of One Mile The Label Sammy Robinson.

The two broke up about two months ago after taking their relationship public via their various social media platforms earlier this year.

Sammy

This will be Simi's first fight.

Ive actually invited her to the fight, she is the love of my life, Simi said.

I was saying to [promoters] George and Matt Rose, Im fighting for love here.

Thats why Im doing this. I thought I need a fight so I can win and then look down the lens and say Hey, I love you, take me back.

Hopefully she comes. Im not too sure yet.

The main thing for me is, I love this girl.

Im a bit of a romantic like that. I thought, What is a big stage close by that I can tell the world I love her?

And this boxing thing jumped in my lap and Im like, This is it.

So hopefully shell come, the boys have been rallying around to try to get her to come.

Hopefully Ill get the win.

instagram

Simi and Hodges are the undercard for the fight between the highly anticipated Nikita Tszyu and Ben Horn stoush.

Robinson is yet to respond to his barrage of requests to attend, according to her social media activity she is instead focusing on her own training and business pursuits.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document AUSTOL0020220718ei7i003pd


The-oz
Morrison speaks of \"Satan's plan\" in Margaret Court's church
Jenna Clarke
958 words
18 July 2022
18:06
The Australian - Online
AUSTOL
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

If Scott Morrison wasn't a politician, he would be a pastor.

Former Prime Minister Scott Morrison has delivered a sermon where he warned people about \"Satan's plan\".

He is worried Australia has been gripped by worry because of the Covid pandemic and said he \"still believes in miracles\" despite the wipe out loss of his government at the Federal election.

Morrison spoke for more than an hour in Perth at the weekend on the invitation of tennis star Margaret Court, the founder of the church who is celebrating her 80 birthday, where he also helped officially open her new Victory Life Church headquarters.

On Sunday Morrison urged parishioners to trust in God above all else.

\"We trust in Him. We don't trust in governments. We don't trust in the United Nations, thank goodness,\" Morrison said.

Morrison's rhetoric while addressing Church congregations would not be surprising or shocking to fellow attendees. This language and teaching is the standard for majority of people watching, listening or streaming.

Scott Morrison speaking at a guest at Margaret Court's Church. Picture: 9 News

He also spoke at length about the rising rates of mental illness in Australia.

Morrison highlighted there were biological issues or brain chemistry that resulted in clinical disorders and sought to link the everyday anxieties to a spiritual deficit.

Morrison added that if people \"gave into\" their worries, they were resigning themselves to \"Satans plan\"

God knows that anxiety is part of the human condition, he said.

He drew parallels between Gods engagements and how counsellors address mental health before declaring if you had faith in Gods plan you didnt need to worry.

No matter how [secular people] might seek to deny it, or even dismiss it, the truth of God stands up and shines, Morrison said.

It was the first time Morrison had visited WA since his election defeat. A loss that came from the overwhelming rejection of the government as the results saw a massive swing from voters away from the Liberal party.

He confirmed his acceptance to appear alongside Court - a divisive public figure due to her anti-gay views - was done so in a \"private capacity\". However, Morrison is still an MP and when parliament starts next week he will be an opposition backbencher earning a publicly funded pay cheque of more than $180,000.

If we wasn't a politician, he'd be a pastor

On the eve of the election back in May Morrison sat down with The Oz and told us exclusively that if he wasn't in politics, he would be a preacher.

\"I probably would have been a church pastor,\" Morrison, a proud Pentecostal Christian, said while adding that you didn't need to be loved to be a good PM, but had to be \"respected and be strong and listen\".

#scottmorrison says he felt misunderstood on the issue of women, which has been identified as central to his election defeat. This interview has been abbreviated. Read more from the interview on theoz.com.au

His address in front of churchgoers in Perth is not entirely surprising.

Morrison made his final ever public comments as Prime Minister in the confines of his regular Church in Sydney's Sutherland Shire the day after the election loss.

Jenny and I and the girls are very grateful to our church family here, Morrison said back in May.

Youve given us a great foundation from which we could walk what has been a very difficult walk, Ive got to tell you, over the last four years.

Whether youre a prime minister, a pastor, running a business, teaching in schools, working in the police force, it doesnt matter. Were each called to trust and obey. And thats the life of faith He calls us to. Thats how we live our faith each and every day, regardless of what your job is, and to express it in how you do that.

He also quoted from the Bible and was seen to wipe away tears.

Margaret Court has a church?

After her world-recording breaking tennis career Court leaned in hard to her faith (something she also never shied away from during her playing days).

Australias greatest ever tennis player established the Victory Life Church in 1995.

Following a call from God to establish a word of faith (and) Pentecostal ministry in the Perth area. Our Vision is to train an army of people who know Christ from within, to take this city and nation for Jesus, the Churchs website states.

The Pentecostal churchs new five-story prayer tower, which was approved for construction back in 2018, opened at the weekend.

Court has been a vocal supporter of the former PM.

Former Australian tennis player Margaret Court now runs a Church in Perth where ScoMo held court at the weekend.

Her husband Barry is a former Liberal party president.

Back in February she publicly prayed Morrison would be re-elected and she previously defended him during his family holiday to Hawaii as bush fires ravaged NSW.

In the 12-months to June 2021, Court's Church received $365,000 in taxpayer dollars - which was the last full financial year of Morrisons Prime Ministership - and is exempt from tax as all churches are.

It also received $283,000 worth of Government funding and grants over the 2019-20 financial year.

Victory Life Treasurer James Chan revealed in August last year the Church also collected $500,000 through the Morrison government's JobKeeper scheme to support its 12 full-time and 13 casual employees.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.
