Document DAITEL0020220704ei750007h


Letters
Go smart, not hard, on Covid
400 words
5 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
20
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

Call it Covid Redux or Covid 2.0: Just when most of us thought or at least hoped that we had put the pandemic behind us, new variants of coronavirus are rearing their highly infectious heads.

And combined with almost zero natural immunity to the flu after two years of lockdowns and other restrictions, Australia is heading into a winter not just of discontent but discomfort, disease and yes even death.

And so, the pressing question is: what do we do?

The first and most obvious answer is not what we did last time. We cannot simply return to the blunt and brutal measures of restricting movement and locking people down.

Only now are we starting to see the true impact of the last wave of lockdowns, ranging from kids falling behind at school to skyrocketing divorce rates to turbocharged inflation, not to mention the collective mental health toll on our nation and especially the young.

Instead, we need to respond smarter, not harder. And that means making sure we are as vaccinated as possible including up to four shots for those in vulnerable cohorts as well as developing new vaccines to target emerging variants.

Tellingly, this is what two leading medical figures have alluded to in recent days, with Queenslands Chief Health Officer John Gerrard pointedly saying he opposes the reintroduction of mask mandates and other restrictions and that we should instead be focusing on extra booster shots for those aged over 65.

Likewise, Griffith University Infectious Diseases and Immunology director Nigel McMillan has said that new targeted vaccines will be the way forward, as well as antiviral treatments.

Again, smarter, not harder.

Because the real hard truth of Covid-19 is that no matter what any of us thought or hoped, the pandemic was never going to be completely behind us.

As the experts have warned us time and again, we need to learn to live with the virus. And yet it is clear from some of the rhetoric about the inevitable rise in cases that many commentators were clearly just paying lip service to this fact or perhaps had failed to adequately comprehend what living with the virus actually entailed. Thankfully, these panicked voices are increasingly marginalised in what is left of the Covid-19 debate, and the vast majority of us simply want to get our lives back.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document DAITEL0020220704ei750005q


OpEd
The real Covid questions
Joe Hildebrand
756 words
2 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
79
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

We still dont know what happened to all the kids who slipped through the cracks during lockdown, writes Joe Hildebrand

IT is the worlds oldest political truism, that you never hold an inquiry unless you know what the outcomes going to be.

And so when Health Minister Mark Butler announces an inquiry into the Morrison governments vaccine deals you can bet your last brass tack that its not going to look good for the former mob.

But we also know this because it was blindingly obvious and universally broadcast, printed and shouted from every rooftop at the time.

So what is the point?

Presumably the new government has access to the contracts without having to order an inquiry into them and is perfectly capable of making better deals on its own.

As things stand now, we know vaccines work, everyone has plentiful access to them and we will soon be manufacturing our own.

There is an old joke that Elviss only drug problem was supply. It is certainly not ours.

And so if there is going to be an inquiry into anything Covid-related, it should be into everything Covid related.

Because I, like millions of others of Australians, have more than a few questions Id like to see answered before the next pandemic rolls around.

Here are just some of them: Do all states and territories in Australia now have well-resourced and state-of-the-art contact tracing that can keep the need for restrictions to a minimum?

Why was NSW able to track and trace so successfully for so long thus avoiding several lockdowns while Victoria was not?

Which restrictions were most effective in preventing the spread of the virus and which were not?

Was the closure of beaches and playgrounds necessary?

How did the lockdowns affect poorer citizens and families required to isolate in apartments and small homes compared to affluent Australians with larger houses and gardens?

How did the restrictions affect blue-collar and self-employed workers who were unable to work from home versus those who could comfortably do so?

What is the efficacy of mask mandates in a mass-vaccinated population? What were the mental health impacts of lockdowns on younger populations versus older populations?

Why did the scanning of QR codes remain compulsory in NSW even after nobody was monitoring or using them?

Why were schools closed against the advice of the nations top medical experts who said they were safe?

How many students learning suffered as a result of school closures? How many Australian children disappeared from the school system after these closures?

And, the biggest question of them all, where are they now?

Lets start local. In NSW it was reported in evidence to a 2020 inquiry set up by the Teachers Federation that after the first lockdown alone more than 3000 public school students simply never returned to school.

Around the same time the charity Save The Children warned that across the globe almost 10 million students could drop out of school because of lockdowns.

For an example, lets go to one of the most difficult and disadvantaged parts of the world.

Our closest neighbour to the north, Papua New Guinea, had no preschool at all until 2020 when UNICEF Australia started a groundbreaking program.

This was a godsend for the children of PNG and a linchpin in the fight against poverty and disadvantage.

Then the lockdowns came.

One pioneering volunteer educator had a class of 24 children. After lockdown only 15 came back.

When we had the lockdown due to Covid-19, some kids went home and were scared to come back after we closed the school for one month, she said.

This was in a report by UNICEF Australia. Its conclusion was unequivocal. UNICEF Australia is calling for schools to be the last places to close and the first to reopen, the report said.

Educators and experts across the board and across the planet have issued the same cry.

And yet here in Australia, one of the most affluent and supposedly transparent democracies in the world, we still dont have an adequate answer on why schools were closed in the first place nor an assurance it will never happen again.

And, most importantly, we still dont know what happened to all the kids who slipped through the cracks. As long as were having an inquiry, how about we have an inquiry into that.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.

Document DAITEL0020220701ei720005h


SaturdayExtra
CENSUS RESULTS - What we now know about Australia
721 words
2 July 2022
Daily Telegraph
DAITEL
Telegraph
71
English
News Pty Limited. No redistribution is permitted.

On the night of Tuesday, August 10, last year, Australians sat down to fill in the 2021 census. The statistics, released this week, reveal a snapshot of a changing nation.

25.5 MILLION people counted in Australia on Census night - excluding overseas visitors

812,728 people identified as being Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (3.2 per cent of the total people counted and an increase of more than 25 per cent since 2016).

167 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages spoken at home in 2021 by 78,656 people.

More than 1m people (1,020,007) arrived in Australia between 2017 and 2021. Four out of five were between 2017 and 2019, before the Covid-19 pandemic.

Almost half of Australians have a parent born overseas (48.2 per cent), while 27.6 per cent reported a birthplace overseas.

India was the largest increase in country of birth outside Australia with 220,000 (217,963) additional people counted moving past China and New Zealand to become the third largest country of birth behind Australia and England.

Second largest increase was Nepal, with 67,752 people.

The top five reported ancestries 29.9% Australian 9.5% Irish 8.6% Scottish 5.5% Chinese

MORE THAN 5.6 million people speak another language other than English at home. Of these 852,706 said they do not speak English well or at all.

Most common languages spoken other than English are Mandarin (685,274 people), and Arabic (367,159).

DEFENCE FORCE 581,139 Australians reported serving or have served in our Australian Defence Force 84,865 are current serving members and 496,276 former serving members. Of the former serving members, 129,437 are men aged between 65-74.

Less than one in seven former members are female, with more than one in five currently serving.

FAMILIES

More than 5.5 million couple families were counted, of which 53 per cent have children living with them and 47 per cent do not have children living with them.

More than 1 million one-parents families recorded for the first time of which four out of five were female parents.

More than 2.5 million families with children aged under 15. 775,000 people over 55 reported looking after other peoples children down from 825,000 in 2016.

More than 1.8m are divorced and 674,590 are separated.

More than 1m are widowed eight out of 10 being female.

Almost 10 million Aussies over the age of 15 were in a registered marriage of these 23,914 were in a same-sex marriage.

HEALTH Almost 4.8 million (4,791,516) people reported having one of the long-term health conditions listed on the Census.

More than half of people born in Greece (56.1 per cent) and Italy (53.7 per cent) reported one or more long-term health condition.

More than 2.2m people reported having a long-term mental health condition, arthritis (2,150,396) or asthma (2,068,020), Asthma is the most commonly reported health condition for 014 year olds, with 7.4 per cent of male children compared to 5.3 per cent of female children.

HOUSING More than 10.8m private dwellings counted on census night 13% Town houses 16% Apartments 70% Houses 550,592 people live in Australias 370,000 (368,943) high rise apartments. More 2.5 million (2,620,903) now live in apartments.

1,043,776 dwellings were unoccupied on Census night such as vacant holiday homes or vacant investment properties.

58,155 were in a caravan on Census night and 29,369 were on a cabin or houseboat.

66 per cent of people own their home outright or with a mortgage, 35 per cent have a mortgage while 30 per cent own their home outright.

VEHICLES 91.3% of households reported having at least one vehicle and more than half (55.1 per cent) reported having two or more vehicles.

RELIGION Christianity is the most-common religion in Australia with 43.9 per cent (down from 52.1 per cent in 2016).

Almost 40 per cent listed no religion up from 30.1 per cent in 2016. 684,002 identified as practising the Hindu faith, while 813,392 practised Islam.

Nationwide News Pty Ltd.
